title: Manhattan Luxury Market Sees ‘Dismal’ Week of Sales
text:
Affluent buyers in Manhattan signed 11 contracts for homes priced at $4 million or more in the week ending Sunday, continuing three months of sluggish luxury sales, according to a roundup of deals from Olshan Realty on Monday.



Last week, was “a dismal total by any measure,” wrote Donna Olshan, president of Olshan Realty and author of the report. It also marked the 12th straight week that the number of high-end deals in Manhattan was below 20—a threshold Ms. Olshan uses to denote a strong market.



More: The Allure of Owning an Australian Island

Multimillion-dollar home deals have declined significantly since July 1, when New York state imposed a set of new transfer taxes on the city, including a new progressive mansion tax on homes over $2 million.



Over the past three months, there have been 176 contracts signed for luxury homes, a 24% decline from the third quarter of 2018.



Those homes that did find buyers are getting bigger price cuts than a year ago, as sellers try to compensate for the added closing costs. Luxury homes that went into contract since July 1 got an 11% discount compared to 8% in the same period last year, according to Olshan.



The total dollar volume of high-end deals has also plummeted since the tax went into effect. Luxury contracts over the last three months totaled $1.33 billion, nearly one-third less than the same period last year, when deals totaled $1.92 billion.

Meanwhile, the biggest deal last week was for an all-cash $27.5 million apartment at a historic co-op building overlooking the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The 12-room apartment has four bedrooms and fireplaces. The uber-exclusive building doesn’t permit mortgage financing.

The second-biggest deal of last week was a Chelsea townhouse asking $13.5 million, marking a massive discount from the $24.5 million the seller was asking when the home first hit the market in August 2016, according to the report.

The mini-compound includes a four-story house and a two-story carriage house, which is connected by a covered pathway, one of the few “horse walks” that still remain in the city.
